title: PRotosCooler - cooling device for RepRap PRotos V1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
the next cooling Thing - but especially for PRotos X-Carrier and Hotend from GRRF one major essencial Part is the "cooling plate" I used aluminium - so it is cooled by the airflow and the PLA or ABS of the device itselve is protected against the heat when the fan is running.
This has also an cooing effect for the air around the printing part in addition of the airflow through the holes. In the newest Version I added some adapter holes to install a water cooled Spiral into the airflow. Cobined with a temperature sensor and a little electronics I can adjust the air temperature which cools the part.
...made some unbelieveable filigran prints with PLA without support material.
In 95% of the pints the water cooling is simply not necessary and a combination of support material and uncooled airflow is perfect.
Replaced my old black one with the uploaded version - finally It was not a bad Idea to split the cooling plate. I used my old alu plate and split it and use a printed PLA rear.
Works well :)
Adjust the plate so that the nozzle extends ~1-2mm
I used it already even with the nozzle - works very well in critical corners and prevents he "up bending" of the layers especially when printing vey overhanging.
e.g. the ears of the Stadford Bunny become nearly prefect....
One weakness is the center hole - I made it 8 mm in my first version - this lead to "material consuption" into the free room where he Hotend sits - particulary when a first layer fails and material gets loose ....really no fun to remove it.
It works great to extend it to the dia of the PLA Part However 100% first layer is more mandatory as usual here !!
At this point i like to advertise the "Dauerdruckplatte" which is sold by Philipp Schlautmann here in germany - got one this week... not cheap but really worth each cent!
First layers are like welded to the bed :) and when cooling down parts can be easily put away... absolutely perfect!

description.text:
Hi Folk
i like challenges, so i decided to join the S.T.E.A.M. - MakeItFloat 
This is my first challenge thingiverse. So I started with my colleague to find a good mix of real solutions for transport of heavy Wight. We found something. This is the first concept or our total 3 ideas for this challenge. Hopefully we have enough time to generate, print and test all 3 concepts.
Focus on this Concept:
  • Print less parts and support structures as possible
  • Carry heavy load -> 2 Euro coins (diameter: 25,75 mm, thickness: 2,20 mm, weight: 8,50 g)
  • Priority: load > design
  • Must be moveable in real test
    • At first I decided to generate some boxes for the coins. 10 coins will fit into a red box at the moment. Boxes can be stacked together later.
    I want to print this on a print area of 200x200x180mm with PLA.
    Files, Instructions for assembly and print settings will come in the end.
    End – 19.06.2015 Update
    Update of concept
    STL file prepared
    Motor added (rubber band solution)
    Now, I need to print and test :) 23.06.2015

title: Mini check valve (for aquarium tubing, using a BB pellet)

description.text:
This is a small check valve that can be used to control the direction of flow in standard aquarium tubing (4mm inner and 6mm outer diameter) and requires a 4.5mm BB pellet.  
As in the cut-out picture of the valve, the main chamber contains a pellet. If the flow comes from above, the pellet rests on a raster and fluid can flow around the pellet. If the flow comes from below, the pellet blocks the tubing on top, going out of the valve. The flow can only go from top to bottom. The direction of flow is indicated on the outside of the valve.

Print the object at full infill without support. You can either choose to print it flat or standing up. There's a few shallow bridges in both versions, but both are printable. I prefer the flat model.  
After printing, insert a BB pellet into the valve. Fit tubes (cut of at a right angle) on both sides and glue them (e.g., with ABS juice) to make an air/water tight connection. If the pellet does not block the tube, make sure the hole on the lockable tube is at least 5mm by drilling it out a bit.

title: Filament Quickchange for Robo 3D, Wade extruders

description.text:
10-6-16 Update
I have been thinking about and modeling a lot with captured and print-in mechanics (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1809355 for an example) and turned my sights to this old gem. I have been developing this for a couple of years and I still love this device. Now it is even easier to print and implement, the pincher being in one piece. You can use a small rubber band up top if you find you occasionally shoot your spring across the room.
 At last, a superfast and easy filament interface for Robo 3D! These parts took an hour to print and have already saved me far more than that in time and frustration. Update: I added a video to show the action here:
https://youtu.be/6kazC2Riodg
Update: I modified the pressure pincher so it doesn't hyperextend and is easier to insert and remove. I also added a version with a smaller footprint (6mm) for smaller springs. The pinch tensioner is adjustable using the stock M4 screws. All you need to do is find a good spring. The one I used is 8mm in diameter, around 30mm long, and very stiff.
Watch this space for updates and tweaks. Feedback is appreciated.

Swap out your old Wade extruder bracket with the one included. It is removed with a phillips and a small socket. I found that I had to remove the large extruder gear to get better access, but when I flipped the screw and nut 180 degrees so that the nut is on the side with wires, the phillips side was more accessible through the holes in the side of the gear for future access. Pop out the pressure bearing and snap it in into the newly printed part and then replace it.
Remove the two long M4 screws and push them through the retainer and thread back into the nuts they normally go to. Adjust the tension here using a small phillips screwdriver.
The pinch lever is hinged with a short piece of 3mm filament or a small screw and nut. I recommend printing the retainer side pieces in a different color from the Wade side so you have an easy visual cue as to how it should be oriented, as in the photos.
I found that it was a little tricky to remove the pressure pincher unless you use a finger to help it through from underneath - still way less onerous than the single screw method, and incredibly less frustrating than the stock option. I have printed a fair amount of pla with no slippage issues as of yet. I have yet to test with wood or flexible filament.
Make sure both sides of the pincher are seated firmly and check that your filament is centered before you print.

description.text:
I decided to build a very large rocket... starting with the Microsoft Saturn V as a base, I extended it's size to 7' 6" tall and sliced it up into manageable chunks by the Polar 3D printer.  The 1st stage is 8" in diameter, which is the maximum diameter of the printer and each chunk is no more than 6" tall, again, the printers build height.  
I printed it entirely in PLA... it took 6 printers about 36 hours to complete.  It used about 4kg of PLA for the entire print with a 2% infill and a 320 micron layer height.  2 Shells for most of it, but some structural elements were 3 shells.  
I built mine in 3 large sections... each connected together by a slip fit P logo pin in the middle so we could easily move it.

Print with at least .8mm shell... I prefer 1.2mm shells... no infill is needed on the Polar 3D printer.  
Simply assemble the parts with hot glue or super glue.   I printed a few P connectors and used them to stack it together.

comments.text: Do I have to print more than one of any of these pieces or are all the necessary pieces their own STLs?

description.text:
This model is going to be a working "steam" powered Riverboat. Twin Paddle Wheels. A rocking beam steam engine. I am designing this model in Tinkercad. I am a total neophyte when it comes to 3d design, up to this point my best design has been a knob for a radio scanner. Update 7/2/15 : The First rev of the complete engine is now posted. All the parts are there but they haven't been tested yet. Goal: To create a 3d printed working "steam" engine that will power a boat using paddle wheels. The boat will need to be buoyant enough to support itself, the engine, the paddle wheels and the "boiler".
The "Boiler" will actually be a reactor, Using hot water, to convert Dry ice to C02 gas, the C02 gas will take the place of steam in this engine. Concerns: A steam engine is usually made to tight tolerances. parts are machined out of metal. I have to print using low resolution simply because I would not have time to print at high res. This means my engine has extra room around the pistons and fittings. Will the tolerances be close enough that the engine functions?
It will be interesting to see if the "boiler" can simply move the piston. since I have never designed a steam engine before and I am simply creating the parts using Tinkercad, I'm not sure about the exact measurements for parts such as the crank arm, to accommodate for this I am designing certain parts to be adjustable and once the correct size has been determined, these parts will be "frozen" in size with glue. Update 7/8/15. The "boiler" can definitely move the piston!
https://youtu.be/PmPnefZgURk Activating the "boiler"
http://youtu.be/AbHvNOdBUkY Boiler running on Hi!
http://youtu.be/Kt9tBcXdJtY Ran into a mechanical issue. I didn't take into account the thickness of the Cylinder lid, so that shortens the actual distance the piston can travel. this would in turn shorten the distance the crank throws. so to adjust for this I have simply printed 3 different size cranks and made them adjustable so that I can take into account the error. I can already see there is huge room for improvements. I invite everybody who is interested to work on this. All files will be posted on Tinkercad so that they can be modified at will. I will start a list of modifications I plan to try after the initial design is finished. Update 7/14/15 As I feared I am running out of time to get all the parts printed, -with the limited time available to me on the library printer, I probably wont be able to get the the hull much less the paddle wheels. - However that I won't finish in time to meet the deadline wont stop me from finishing the project, This has been a fantastic learning experience. At this point the main linkages are done. piston > crankshaft, and then in this video I show that the piston works when the cylinder is mounted to the valve manifold. - simply blocking the manifold with my finger backs up the pressure to move the piston. Next step is to create the instructions and make sure all the current pieces are up to date. Next pieces to print are the piston for the valve and the valve cam wheel. that should be all the pieces to make the engine functional. I will try very hard to get the hull done too. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_qziQgTGsbk 7-14-15 update2 replaced all the files with updated versions (single files to make printing easier)

Future Modifications:
a new design for the reactor/boiler. I am using a small soda bottle, my safety valve is a rubber band holding the lid on. The narrow neck of the bottle means it is difficult to load the boiler with dry ice. a better design would have a larger opening to accommodate bigger pieces of dry ice and it would have a better designed safety valve and a better way of introducing warm water into the boiler. a simple improvement would be to make the piston powered in both directions, up and down, this would double the power with just a little modification. a better design for the manifold valve, perhaps a rotary valve instead of a piston.
This was designed from scratch using Tinkercad.

The long lost Parachute roundabout model had ones existed in Al-Wakrah city, Qatar...and we, people who live in Qatar, miss it so dearly. The Parachute Roundabout model is part of a larger augumented reality project called In Memory of the Roundabouts. In Memory of the Roundabouts is a critical design in which virtual, non-existing iconic structures of the city are projected into reality to recreate that relationship or empathy to recall a certain memory. It questions the value of the existence of such structures. It’s virtual appearance of being semi-transparent and having an angel
halo and wings emphasizes the idea of a no-longer existing structure. It’s virtual ability to be adjusted and modified via the user gives it the characteristic and the ability to be located anywhere at anytime. Having that opportunity to project virtual structures into real spaces gives the use the chance to recreate that empathic relationship with the roundabout.

This model was constructed by looking at older photographs of the roundabout. Outlines of model were illustrated in Illustrator CC and were exported as a .SVG file. The outlines / roundabout illustration was then imported to 123D Design and was extruded and constructed as a 3D model. Parts of the model is all combined in one piece so that it can be properly 3D printed. Printing with support material is HIGHLY recommended.

description.text: This is a modern design 1.5 inch square wire holder for cord organization under and behind desks and media centers. It is designed to be easy to mount with double-sided tape, hot glue, or magnets. If you like this design, you can donate Bitcoin to 15G6EsYbMQ8jMatCevpYPsmtBQVXBM3hKG.
Mount a dial Gauge inside your Thing-o-Matic so leveling the print bed is easy.  Mounts to the Mk7 extruder plate.

This is designed to be used with this dial indicator (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NPPBVK?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00). The clearance hole is 6 mm, the sleeve is 11 mm. Shim in the dial indicator to get a tight-fit. I used a twisty-tie. Use some of your favorite M3 nut adapters and m3 screws to attach it to the plate.

title: 3DR Iris+ arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Work in progress! This should allow you to print replacement arm for your IRIS+ quadcopter. 3DR at some point very unfriendly refused to share 3D model of this part despite not having ones in stock. I tried to create similarly functional part last night. Enjoy and please post your results.  
Using 40% infill with 4 perimeters and PLA filament new arm weight almost 12g more than original one, but PLA is about 20% heavier than ABS, so if curling issues could be solved, potentially part printed from ABS should weight about the same as original one.

So far I believe 4 perimeters (using typical settings for 0.35 nozzle) and 50%-70% infill should do it. It is probably best to print it upside down. So far I tried ABS and PLA. ABS soon started curling (despite enclosed printer), PLA turned out much better overall. Will see how it holds up in the air.  
I was able to reuse insert brass nuts from old broken arm. I used heat gun for that, but it should be possible to remove and re-install using high-power soldering iron too i think.

title: Replicator 2 Top Vacuum form mold Scan

description.text: I got tired of using a clear plastic container from insert hardware store name here to keep dust out and heat in. So I made a vacuum form mold by hand out of foam and plaster.

use a very big 3dprinter to print, or slice into parts with a utility like 123D make, and make it with a laser cutter? mill it with a foam cnc router and cover it with plaster?  There is the scan, and then there is the smooth version.  
To pull a top, use 0.03" to 0.06" clear PTEG 24" x 24" sheet.  This project assumes access to a 24" x 24" vacuum former. Trim the edge to dims of the top of the Rep2. glue disk magnets onto the top for easy on/off.

it would be interesting if one could put these on each arm and then be able to set the angle on which the motors sit, rather than having tilted blocks under each arm.

comments.author: Tjm_27

comments.text: That design does seem possible, but note that this tilts the motor on the axis of the arm, which is not the forward axis of the quadcopter on a standard zmr.  The way I fly though, it would certainly end up broken.  I think having the gimbal on the back rotor only would be what protects it.  And also, a servo for each arm would add significant weight, even if they were very small servos.  Still, it's a cool idea.  People are doing gimbaled motors and getting away with it on other designs, you should look into it.

description.text:
I improved the case found from here https://www.myminifactory.com/object/case-for-lcd-screen-5681
Original design are great but took me hours to screw the case together because the main idea is to screw it right on the case. I improved it by enlarging the screw hole by adding nut slot at the back and the screw will be from the front and it will be flushed, flat with the case surface. This is to make it easier to assemble the case to the board. This is also enables you to use longer screw to mount this case by having the screw go through at the back of the case. Once again I didn't create the this item, I only improved the screw holes so that you can fasten it with nut and will be much easier to assemble it

title: Printrbot simple makers edition (1405) ZY Plate for stock Y axis

description.text:
this YZ Plate was based on measurements from iamjonlawrence designs, and sambert20 remix:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:372467
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723004
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:799068 it is a simplified version of iamjonlawrence's no sag YZ plate, it has less volume, and the mounting points for iamjonlawrence belt mechanism have been removed, like bert20's remix this YZ plate is meant to be used with the stock 1405 Y axis. (to print it on your stock 1405 printrbot you need to remove the printing skirt on Cura, go to Expert>Open Expert Settings and change line count of the skirt to 0) UPDATE 0: I have just realized a few faults on the model, this YZ table will reduce the Y travel of the printer. to understand why read the comment section here: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:134670 UPDATE 1: the distance between the bearings was reduced to improve Y travel I HAVE NOT PRINTED IT YET, because my printrbot heater element is broken, if you print it please leave feedback

description.text:
I created this logo/badge to attach to some of the models that I will upload, just to give them a personal touch. The jet is based off an F-22 and "JP" is my initials. I am not expecting to get a whole bunch of downloads or views of this, but I still thought that I should upload this, just in case some people start asking why this is appearing on some of the models I upload. The edge blends I created in the NX .prt file did not carry over when I converted it to an .stl file using Inventor. Compare pic #1 and pic #3 and you will see the difference.
  • I designed this during another 30 minute lunch break at work. I enjoy having quick 30 minutes personal projects while at work because it gives me a break from my other projects and allows me to be more creative and just throw a design together.

description.text: A nozzle cleaning tool for a plastic extruding 3D printer. This is a ball point pen spring straightened out. It's much stronger than a guitar string and doesn't leave you with an incomplete set of replacement guitar strings. The end needs to be straightened as straight as possible. Haven't measured it exactly but it fits perfectly into a .4mm nozzle from the bottom. Adding a generic extruder nozzle model to files for info only.

The end needs to be straightened as straight as possible. Haven't measured it exactly but it fits perfectly into a .4mm nozzle from the bottom. Preheat the empty nozzle, then holding just the tip with the needle nose pliers, start poking it into the nozzle hole from the bottom. If there is any snag, then it is a clog. A totally clean nozzle will allow feeding of the spring wire tool from the bottom all the way up through the extruder and poke out the filament input hole. If an obstruction is encounter, carefully stroke the wire in and out, until the snag gives way and there is a gooey feeling. At this point, it is possible to have a very small cotton ball with just a small drop of acetone and wrap around the tool, then stroking in and out in bigger strokes, wiping the shaft of the tool while stroking. Nothing like the feeling of a stroked and cleaned tool.

Apologies for the awful(ly good) pun! The stick dude is printed from solid PLA. He is more dense than both water and olive oil, but is able to surf on the boundary between the two! This is my entry into the #MakeItFloat competition. I started out by trying to make an object that would float on the boundary between oil and water simply by making it less dense than water and more dense than oil. But unfortunately PLA is quite a bit more dense than water, and it didn't look like it would work. Even the maximum concentration of salt dissolved in water is still less dense than PLA. But during my little test with scraps of plastic I noticed something even more interesting! The oil has a lower surface tension and sticks to the plastic (ie. wets it) more strongly than the water does, and the buoyancy of the oil holds the piece lifted to the surface even though it's heavier than both liquids! The surfer doesn't float by displacing a greater mass of water or oil than itself, it is actually held up by adhesion to the floating oil. Video: http://youtu.be/tUhjWFgZYio Tip: dissolving salt in the water decreases the difference in density between it and the dude, which helps make the surfing effect stronger.

IMPORTANT: Print with 100% infill!  
I'd suggest setting your quality settings to maximum to get a good print. The models are very small. For better print quality try printing a bunch of the guys (or add another, bigger object to the print job) at the same time to give each layer time to cool down before the next one starts.  
"Hands Dude" prints without support, but "Feet Dude" will need supports to be generated.  
Tip: add a dude to the water before pouring oil in, then lift him to the surface with tweezers. If you just drop him in through the oil he'll end up coated in gobs of it.

author: Finmann

title: 100W Flashlight Parts (Handle, Feets, Poti Knob, Boost Cover)

description.text:
These are the parts I used for my 100W Flashlight. Idea: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c--5c3Egv4E I know, mine is not looking like the one in the Video, but it's smaller, lighter and easyer to build (if you got an 3D printer ;) ). I don't know what heat sink I used (I found it in my cellar).
It could be an arctic heat sink 80x80x35.
I think a XILENCE l110 will work, too. But no guarantee! Parts I used:
  • Unknown Heat Sink 80x80x35
  • Unknown Fan 80x80
  • One more Fan 40x40
  • Fan grill 80x80
  • Fan grill 40x40
  • 100W LED Chip (warm white, 32-36V, 3-3,5A, 7k-8k Lumen)
  • 150W Step-Up Boost (adjusted to 31,5V)
  • Selfmade Voltage Divider (Schematic in Video)
  • 10kOhm Wirewound 10-turn Potentiometer
  • Mini Step-Down Module for the Fans (adjusted to 11V)
  • 5 XT60 connectors
  • Thick wires
  • Screws
  • 12V Vehicle Jack

  • Old 19V Notebook AC/DC Adapter

  • Collimator Lens (still waiting for it)
    • 3D Parts:
    "Boost Plate" comes between aluminum heat sink and circuit board. You may have to resize it a bit, depends on the Boost you use.
    "Cooler Holder" is used as a handle.
    "Cooler Holder Poti" used as a handle with potentiometer.
    "Cooler Stand" used as a foot (maybe print twice).
    "Cooler Stand Text" is a foot with text on it (not nice to print ): ).
    "Spacer" is a spacer between foot one and two.
    I never would have guessed. :D
    "StepUp Cover" protects the Step-Up Boost.
    "StepUp Cover 2" protects the Step-Up Boost (Fan fits better).
    "Poti Knob" is a customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54024 I wanted to use "LEDFocus" as an adapter for an old projector-lens but.... Nah... Bad Idea. Too hot :o

Just print it and don't forget to turn some things 180° around. Be careful with "Cooler Stand Text", maybe use a smaller nozzle to get a nice text. Created your own "Poti Knob" with the Customizer:
http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=54024 Good Luck :)

A stand for AeroPressâ„¢ style coffee makers. The stand provides stability when applying pressure to the plunger as the coffee maker no longer rests directly on a narrow and possibly unbalanced cup. AeroPressâ„¢:
http://aerobie.com/products/aeropress.htm
http://www.aeropresscoffee.co.uk/ Made at the London Hackspace:
http://london.hackspace.org.uk/

1) Laser cut the design in 5mm acrylic:
  • To ensure a tight fit between components, the kerf of your cutter should be considered. The DXF was generated with a kerf of 0.1mm - this should be suitable for most laser cutters.
  • If you need to adjust the kerf you can modify the components named "hole*" in the SketchUp model or manually modify the DXF. Note: The SketchUp model has no kerf adjustment!
  • Ensure that any text paths are configured for etching, not cutting. When using transparent acrylic, I usually flip the text and engrave on the reverse side of a component to provide an unbroken facing surface.
    • 2) Assemble the components and fix them with a suitable glue. 3) Optionally fix the top hexagonal template using 4 hex screw cap bolts - gravity works just as well in this case. 4) Boil a kettle, grind some beans, brew, plunge, enjoy coffee!

author: alphaflight83

description.text: This is the SSV Normandy from Mass Effect 1. The Normandy, a state-of-the-art stealth frigate designed by the Earth Systems Alliance and Turian Hierarchy, was commissioned in 2183. I created this model by referencing Alex Jerjomin's excellent tutorial and source files at http://www.3dm3.com/tutorials/normandy/.

If you choose to print off "Normandy.thing", I recommend using High quality with default settings. Make sure to print with raft and supports. The resulting model will be 15cm (6 inches) in length.  
I've also included the ".stl" files for the five components that make up the ship.  
After printing, remove the support plastic from the components. Take the hull (the largest component) and sand the ends of the four struts for a few seconds. Use superglue to connect the components.

Molecular structure of water at temperature < 0ºC (ice). Modeled in Avogadro and imported into Blender using a Python script that I wrote by myself.

comments.text: What did you do to get this from Avogadro to an STL?
comments.author: neonorangehats

comments.text: I wrote a Python script that works in Blender. This script reads the .CML file from Avogadro and with that info, Blender "imports" the model. Then, you just export it in STL or whatever. But for 3D print, first I have to join all atoms and bonds, and then I do the export to STL. Hope this has helped you.
